Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 07:25PM bethcw wrote: I also had long hair. I had it buzz cut down to about an inch. From there I let it fall out on it's own. I ended up clipping what was left at the end of chemo off so that it would grow back evenly. The day I clipped it down to an inch was the most emotional. I wore a mix of 2 different wigs and various wraps. My husband didn't like me in a wig (he said it didn't look like me).
Posts.Title: How did you deal with losing your hair? taraw413 lorenar

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2013 03:32PM - edited Jun 20, 2013 03:32PM by bethcw I also had a vound vac (and a skin graft) in March after a failed DIEP attempt.  My skin graft was paper thin, right on top of my ribs, and definitely stuck and not moving.  Now it is starting to look like more normal skin.  I just finished 6 weeks of physical therapy and that has made a world of difference for me!  You need to have a PT that is a certified lymphadema therapist (look for PT, CLT-LANA certification). My PT did a lot of myofascial release techniques with me, and they really worked wonders!  I almost have normal range of motion and the skin now moves like it is supposed to.  I would definitely give it a try.
Posts.Title: Anyone's Skin Stuck to Chest After Wound Vac Treatment? TIGHT! Strike_Two Strike_Two

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2012 10:21AM bethcw wrote: Hi ladies. My new avatar is my new work ID picture that was taken this morning.  I am about 10 1/2 months PFC.  I've had 3 trims when it first started growing back and one "real" haircut.  I've always had long hair, so I am trying to use this time to experiment with some short styles that I would have never tried before.  It took me a while to remember how to style it again.  It was hard to switch from the "towel dry" hairstyle that someone else mentioned, but I am starting to get the hang of it.  Each stage has it's own challenges - lol.  Hang in there ladies it will be back before you know it! Beth

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 08:02AM bethcw wrote: Hello ladies!  I just wanted to jump in here and offer some encouragement.  I traveled the same road starting last July, and finished up on November 1.  The unknown was bad for me too, my most anxious nights were the night before my first AC, and the night before my first T.  It is not fun, but it is not unmanageable.  My cancer center did an awesome job with helping to manage side effects.  They gave me a sheet that had a schedule of drugs to take each day, and I followed it religiously.  It really is important to stay ahead of the nausea, take something before you need it!  One of the best perscriptions I had for nausea was Emend.  If it is not in your bag of tricks already, ask your doctor about it!  Drink tons of water - before, during, and after the infusion to flush that stuff out of your system as soon as possible.  Expect to start losing hair about 2-3 days after the 2nd infusion.  That seems to be the consensus for that timetable.  I buzz cut my long hair down to about an inch, and let it fall out from there.  I didn't end up losing all of my hair, but at the end, I shaved down what was left so that it would start to grow back more evenly.  The neulasta shot is also important.  My doctors decided to let me skip the one after my 7th infusion, because I had been doing so well.  When it came time for my last infusion, I had to wait an extra week because my white count was too low.  Talk about heartbreaking!  Anyway, best of luck to you all, know that you can do this!
Posts.Title: JANUARY AC & T FIGHTERS!! beckyv bethcw

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2012 07:34PM bethcw wrote: I went back to work topless after the Christmas/New Year holiday, which was about 9 weeks PFC.  I was terrified, but I figured it was a new year, so why not!  It helped a lot that my husband told me that he liked me better without the wig.  I actually thought it may have been a bit early, but was tired of wearing the wigs.  I sometimes have insecurities, but mostly don't care anymore what people think.  It is who I am for now.  I have almost always had long hair, but have to admit I am enjoying not having to worry about styling my hair these days!

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2012 04:35PM bethcw wrote: I have been lurking on this forum since I started chemo back in July, and finally got around registering.  It has been a great help to me, so I thought it was time to post.  My tumor was a mix of ILC and IDC.  I read earlier that someone described theirs as barbell shaped. That is the way my area was described as well with the whole area measuring over 6cm.  I had all of my lymph nodes removed during my UMX.  My surgeon did a SNB during my surgery, and both of my sentinal nodes came back positive, so he removed the rest of them at that time.  Thankfully, the rest turned out to be negative.  I do have a bit of remorse since all of the rest were taken out, and then ended up being negative, but better safe than sorry I guess.... I have not really had a lot of issues related to the lymph nodes being gone, it is important to start stretching that side out as soon as you can.  Reaching overhead continues to be my biggest challenge.  My underarm can sometimes be tight due to some cording, but the best thing I have done for that is seeing a physical therapist.  She has been a trememdous help in stretching, massaging, and teaching me what to expect and to be on the lookout for as far as lymphedema.
Posts.Title: Calling All with Tumors 6 cm + J-Bug CaliKelly

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2012 09:53AM bethcw wrote: I received all of my treatments at the NC Cancer Hospital at UNC-Chapel Hill.  I had all of my records transferred there as soon as my regional hospital started talking about a biopsy, and it was the best decision I could have made.  I received excellent care, had great experiences with, and highly recommend all of my providers.
Posts.Title: Recommendations for high risk docs/ oncology centers? yolo TiredProf

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2012 09:42AM bethcw wrote: I just had my first mammogram following my diagnosis last year.  They told me at my survivorship visit that annual mammograms on my remaining breast would be my plan.  However, I also have dense tissue, and was diagnosed with a mixture of ILC and IDC.  At my next appointment with my BS, I plan to ask for periodic MRI's.
